newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Vols on tech stock options rising.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Vols on tech stock options rising.

text.p: Volatilities on leading technology stocks were rising as investors were busy buying puts and calls amid rallies in the underlying shares, traders said Thursday.

"It appears to me they're buying volatility even at these levels, which are relatively high for the last few months," said Jesse Stamer, a designated primary market maker at the Chicago Board Options Exchange.
"They're buying both puts and calls, so volatility's increasing a bit here," he said.
At 1130 CST/1730 GMT, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index .IXIC was up 6.80 at 1,361.97, just shy of its session high.
A rally in semiconductor stocks led the broader group higher. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index, was up 7.72 points, or 2.85 percent, at 279.02.
Options on the index were not particularly busy as investors centered on options on the individual stocks.
Matt Zahner, a lead market maker at the Pacific Stock Exchange, said investors were focused on the industry's leading stocks.
"It's happening selectively," he said. "Basically the strong are getting stronger.

"You have a lot of peripheral stocks that are more risky and I don't see a lot of people coming in to buy those," he said. "People are looking to buy industry leaders like IBM, Intel and Applied Materials."
At the Pacific Stock Exchange, options volume was led by Micron Technology Inc, Microsoft Corp and 3Com Corp. All three underlying stocks were up solidly.
Hank Nothnagel, senior vice president of options trading at EVEREN Securities in Chicago, said he had crossed some sizable orders in Micron, most of them buy orders.
"There's a big drop-off after the main ones," Zahner said. "As you look at them across the board, the ones that are trading are the industry leaders."
He agreed that volatilities on those options were on the rise.
Volatilities had spiked up on several of the technology company options ahead of quarterly earnings reports, only to collapse once the news was out.
"Now there's other, more fundamental things happening in the industry, and volatility in those bellwether stocks is picking up," Zahner said.
"The scuttlebutt around the floor in general has been that volatility has been pretty low" but is increasing, he added.
The Nasdaq composite has spent the last two trading sessions finding a bottom after correcting off its record close of 1,388.06 set on January 22.
